content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Easy puzzle it would better suited for shortest mode but doable under 5 minutes.

Nice contribution.
However I believe you should change some of the terms in the statement as they are not technically correct.
For instance you cannot have a "chord" with two notes, let alone one. You could however say it's a series of notes, as in a melody for instance.
Then I believe the verb "transpose" is closer to what you are asking than "modulate", (although technically still not correct since you have to take en-harmonics into consideration.)
It's mainly just nitpicking but I fear it could confuse those with knowledge of musical theory.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Slightly tougher than the average, but doable in 5 minutes. Nice and interesting mainly for shortest, which gives a wide variety of solutions, I got to 109 chars, but could be less. Great one, thanks!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear statement; easy enough without being an obvious one-liner.
Not too dependent on knowledge of musical theory.
Typo in goal: "... and they and cycled ..."
I've tried to make it simple yet realistic
Thanks for the corrections! I indeed translated the terms not quite well. Edited

It is simple and fun to code, but unfortunately not realistic, and won't help her to learn how to play the piano. Quite the opposite actually :) 

Music thoery is too much not respected here for that :) You cannot call that "transposition" from a musical perspective. C E  +1 would have to be Bb D (or possibly C# E#). C# F cannot be a transposition of C E.

I am not sure what is the right term to use, though. But not a musical one for sure if you do not want to confuse peuple with knowledge of musical theroy.

But nice simple coding exercise !

Yeah I did not want to dwelve in the complexities of enharmonic equivalences, which would be a whole other story in terms of difficulty. But I think the most problematic thing was the use of the term "chord" which has now been corrected.
(Chromatic) transposition is in fact what is asked in the statement but indeed the output does not conserve the original interval, which I would not expect for a clash anyway.
One way to get around this is to assign a unique name to every key of one octave on the piano and then speak only in terms of piano key shifts instead of semitones, but would this be any less confusing for musicians?

The task is described clearly and very shortly, so either without any music knowledge (even key names) or with too much knowledge, it's solvable in under 5 minutes. Plus, tests are pretty helpful for those who got confused for some reason.
